references: In the proposed approach, we assume there existing semantics tasks and logical relations between questions i.e. entailment graphs as seen in the recent GQA data set [11]. In this data set, there are ùíØ=48ùíØ48\mathcal{T}=48 semantic tasks and their relational semantic logic formulae, listed in Table 7 and Table 8 in the Supplementary Materials respectively. Table 1 shows an example of semantic tasks and their relations along side correspondent questions and answers. This work aims to utilise this prior knowledge to find consistent answers by correctly recognising semantic tasks and enforcing their logical entailment. In other words, we enforce a consistency by maximising satisfaction of known structural entailment between semantic tasks and answers. This is equivalent to minimizing our proposed consistency-augmented loss derived from such logic. In Subsection 3.1, we formally define answer and semantic task recognition problems. Then, we describe structures in families of questions and mention availability of such structures in GQA‚Äôs data set in Subsection 3.2. Subsection 3.3 contains formulation of our proposed consistent logic and how T-norm is used to translate such logic into a continuous loss function.

To create a family of questions, we leverage semantic strutures in GQA dataset [11] as each question this dataset has a field ‚Äôargument‚Äô. Hence, it enables usage of SQL for grouping related questions about the same subject / object existing in the visual knowledge - an image. In addition, these questions have specific sub-fields ‚Äôsemantic‚Äô and ‚Äôentailed‚Äô which label semantic-tasks and describe their relationship to other questions in the same family. Furthermore, fixed relational structures of question families are provided in GQA dataset as entailment graphs between semantic tasks (c.f. Fig 14 in Supplementary material of [11]). Figure 2 illustrates a structure of a question family in GQA dataset. Table 1 shows a family batch of six questions with unique semantic tasks, logically related to each other w.r.t. entailment graphs in Fig. 2. A family may have questions corresponding to semantic tasks and their relations e.g. solid lines if Fig. 2 but usually missing links appear e.g. dashed links in Fig. 6 in the Supplementary Material.

S4.T2.caption: Table 2: Performance comparison between Original, Hybrid and Logic experiments on MAC network in Accuracy, Consistency and Distribution metrics. For the distribution metric, the lower the better. For other metrics, the higher the better.
S4.T2.table:
Metrics Original Hybrid Logic
Accuracy 55.80% 55.47% 56.01%
Consistency 74.54% 77.49% 79.21%
Distribution 6.43 6.25 5.78
references: Table 2 show results across these three different experiments w.r.t. to different metrics recommended by Hudson et al. [11]. Though the full-set of recommended metrics include 7 statistical metrics for the overall dataset and 10 different accuracy for subsets according to categories of semantic tasks mentioned in Table 4 of the Supplementary Material, we focus on three most important metrics Accuracy, Consistency and Distribution, shown in Table 2 to argue for advantages of using hybrid-batch data arrangement and consistency-augmented losses. First is the Accuracy metric, the overall accuracy of predicted answers given ground-truth answers regardless of its semantic types or whether they are binary or open questions. Second is the ‚ÄôConsistency‚Äô metric measuring accuracy performance over groups of entailed questions given provided entailment relations in the test-dev partition. The third metric is Distribution, a Chi-square distance between distributions of predicted and ground-truth answers. This ‚ÄôDistribution‚Äô metric provides a measure of statistical consistency of predicted answers over the whole test-dev dataset. The smaller ‚ÄôDistribution‚Äô metric is, the more similar between predicted and ground-truth distributions of answers are. Hence, the more consistency predicted answers as ground-truth answers are almost always consistent.

Regarding to ‚ÄôAccuracy‚Äô metric performance between three experiments in Table 2, Hybrid is comparable to Original; meanwhile, Logic‚Äôs result is slightly better than both. This means introduction of hybrid batches, multi-task frameworks and the proposed consistency-augmented loss do not hinder the overall accuracy and even slightly improve the performance of VQA machine in this metric. In contrast to only slight improvement in ‚ÄôAccuracy‚Äô, we notice significant improvement nearly 3% in ‚ÄôConsistency‚Äô metrics when hybrid-batches are used in training phases, Hybrid column, instead of batches of random samples, Original column of Table 2. Further 2% improvement in ‚ÄôConsistency‚Äô metric is spotted when the proposed loss function of consistency rule in Eqn 3.3 is added into the multi-task loss. In brief, roughly 5% improvement, shown in Logic experiment‚Äôs Consistency metric, is spotted in comparison with Original‚Äôs experiment. Finally, the improvement in consistency of predicted outputs by this proposal is confirmed by ‚ÄôDistribution‚Äô metric, statistical consistency measurement across the distributions of all 1845 unique answers. Table 2 shows that distribution of predicted answers produced in Hybrid is only slightly better than that of Original‚Äôs result; meanwhile, far more similarity between answers of Logic‚Äôs experiments and the ground-truth answers is spotted in comparison with those of Original or Hybrid experiments.

When comparing Original and Hybrid experiments in Table 2, we can see small difference in almost all metrics except ‚ÄôConsistency‚Äô. The consistency, accuracy across groups of entailed questions, is almost 3% higher when structured data are provided and duo-task loss La‚Äãn‚Äãs++Lt‚Äãs‚Äãk+subscriptsuperscriptùêøùëéùëõùë†subscriptsuperscriptùêøùë°ùë†ùëòL^{+}_{ans}+L^{+}_{tsk} are employed. Involving the proposed logic loss with the mentioned consistent logic formulae further improves the consistency by 2%. Overall, there is 5% in consistency score between the proposed Logic and Original experiment. Furthermore, consistent logic loss produce predicted answers of which distribution is much closer to the ground-truth answer distribution and improve the overall accuracy, as shown in metrics ‚ÄôDistribution‚Äô and ‚ÄôAccuracy‚Äô of Table 2.

Semantic Tasks Questions Answers Original Hybrid Logic

references: Table 3 shows anecdotal performance and differences between Original, Hybrid and Logic experiments. In this example, Logic has the best accuracy as it answers both questions with ‚ÄôexistRelTrue‚Äô semantic tasks correctly and consistently; meanwhile, Original and Hybrid experiments give none and one correct answer. Though Logic gave wrong answers to all three questions about queryRel, it demonstrates its consistency by giving the same answer to three different questions with the same semantic task. Meanwhile, Original and Hybrid change their answers despite that three questions are about the same object. Logic may predict wrong answers but it is at least consistent in comparison with Original and Hybrid.

references: In the proposed approach, we assume there existing semantics tasks and logical relations between questions i.e. entailment graphs as seen in the recent GQA data set [11]. In this data set, there are ùíØ=48ùíØ48\mathcal{T}=48 semantic tasks and their relational semantic logic formulae, listed in Table 7 and Table 8 in the Supplementary Materials respectively. Table 1 shows an example of semantic tasks and their relations along side correspondent questions and answers. This work aims to utilise this prior knowledge to find consistent answers by correctly recognising semantic tasks and enforcing their logical entailment. In other words, we enforce a consistency by maximising satisfaction of known structural entailment between semantic tasks and answers. This is equivalent to minimizing our proposed consistency-augmented loss derived from such logic. In Subsection 3.1, we formally define answer and semantic task recognition problems. Then, we describe structures in families of questions and mention availability of such structures in GQA‚Äôs data set in Subsection 3.2. Subsection 3.3 contains formulation of our proposed consistent logic and how T-norm is used to translate such logic into a continuous loss function.

Finally, relations between semantic tasks, as illustrated in Fig 2, are written as First-Order Logic (FOL) functions. The full list of relations are listed in Table 8 of the Supplementary Material. With respect to these relations, several potential logic formulae œàùúì\psi for consistent answers can be hypothesized and following are two examples,

In addition, there are further entailment relations between semantic tasks of questions in the same family, described in Sub-section 3.2. Such entailment relations can be translated into logic-loss as well. In GQA data set, there are 45 different possible entailed relations between a pair of different questions x1,x2subscriptùë•1subscriptùë•2x_{1},x_{2}, listed in a supplementary Table 8. For each entailment, the logical relation between a question pair is either residual-imply ‚áí‚áí\Rightarrow or bi-residuum ‚áî‚áî\Leftrightarrow.
